intro: Abutilon oxycarpum var. malvifolium, commonly known as the velvetleaf abutilon, is a species of flowering plant in the mallow family, Malvaceae. It is characterized by its soft, velvety leaves that are typically lobed or deeply divided, giving it a distinctive appearance. The plant produces showy, lantern-shaped flowers that range in color from yellow to orange, often attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in warm climates and is often found in tropical and subtropical regions. Its botanical features make it a popular choice for ornamental gardening and ecological landscaping.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abutilon oxycarpum var. malvifolium is primarily native to Southeast Asia, including countries such as India, Sri Lanka, and parts of Indonesia. It is commonly found in tropical and subtropical regions, particularly in areas with warm, humid climates. This plant thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in open woodlands or along riverbanks. It is also present in some regions of Africa, such as Kenya and Tanzania. Due to its ornamental value, it has been introduced to other parts of the world, but its native range remains largely within Southeast Asia and eastern Africa.
